results.title: The Broken covenant
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Many of Australia’s urban First Nations people live in appalling physical conditions and are seen by some Australians as outcasts. But to Father Ted Kennedy, a Catholic priest who works in the inner-city suburb of Redfern, many of these marginalised people retain an essential quality of life missing in white society.

results.title: Familiar places
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Anthropologist Peter Sutton is taken by an Aboriginal family, the Naponans, to map hereditary clan country in northern Queensland where they hope to live one day. To the children it is all new; to an old man it brings back vivid memories. [Source: https://aiatsis.gov.au/publication/35836 Last accessed 12/7/2023]

results.title: Takeover
results.creator_credit: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: On 13th March, 1978 the Queensland government announced its intention to take over the management of the Aurukun Aboriginal Reserve from the Uniting Church. The people of Aurukun complained bitterly, believing that the Church was more sympathetic to their aims and fearing that the State was merely seeking easier access to the rich bauxite deposits on their Reserve. When the Federal Government took the side of the Aurukun people the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Sons of Namatjira
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Keith Namatjira and his relatives paint in the style of his famous father, Albert and live in an artist’s camp on the outskirts of Alice Springs. The film highlights problems which the Namatjiras confront in their relationship with the world outside their community.

results.title: They used to call it sandy blight
results.creator_credit: Douglas Stanley and Nomad Films International
results.brief_description: Designed to reveal the problem of trachoma and other serious eye diseases common in remote First Nations communities. Health problems, housing and general living conditions are also looked at. Shows how medical attention can help to alleviate problems.

results.title: Two laws. Part 4: Living with two laws
results.brief_description: Part 4 of the innovative film “Two laws”, on the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. This part describes the present movement back to traditional land, the assertion of ceremonial practice and the setting up of cattle out-stations. The other parts of the film are: “Police times”, “Welfare times” and “Struggle for our land”. Made with the assistance of the Australian Film Commission.

results.title: Bitter Springs
results.creator_credit: Ralph Smart, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description: The year is 1900 and sheepfarmer Wally King is given the rights to territory in the Australian outback. He sets out with his family to claim the land, but having made the hazardous 600 mile journey through wilderness, they find that the “permanent water” - Bitter Springs - is home to First Nations people who refuse to relinquish it. A violent struggle develops , which can only be resolved when the white man’s gun is replaced by compromise. Remarkably, for its time, the film attempts some balance in presenting the point of view of encroaching European settlers and First Nations claims for land rights. Starring Tommy Trinder, Chips Rafferty, Gordon Jackson, Jean Blue, Michael Pate, Charles Tingwell, Nonnie Piper, Nicky Yardley and Henry Murdock.

results.title: Two laws. Part 1. Police times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 1 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. This part looks at Borroloola in the 1930’s, dramatically reconstructing a conflict there between First Nations people, new white settlers and police in 1933. The other parts of the film are: “Welfare times”, “Struggle for our land” and “Living with two laws”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Two laws. Part 3: Struggle for our land
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 3 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. Describes attachment to land, conflict over sacred sites, the 1977 Borroloola land claim and the bargaining strategy of the people with the government, the cattle stations and the mining company. The other parts of the film are “Police times”, “Welfare times”, “Living with two laws”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Dugong! Dugong!
results.creator_credit: Australian Museum, Howard Hughes and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Commencing with the telling of a legend about the dugong, the film then shows the hunting, killing and cooking of the dugong by the First Nations people living on Mornington Island. Hunting is now done by motor boat as opposed to the traditional method using nets, which is re-enacted.
